body: I think a `fs.File` probably only makes sense within it's `fs.Filesystem` and carries an implicit reference to it's creating `fs.Filesystem`, meaning that the `CopyFileRange` function doesn't need to take a parameter for the `fs`. Apart from that I think it's the proper solution. The `fs.File`s as currently envisioned in the other PR support both `io.ReaderAt` and `io.WriterAt` meaning `CopyRange` has a simple, generic implementation. It can then also check for the possibility of the source file supporting a `CopyFileRangeTo(...)` method or something like that.

FWIW, if someone can get a PR put together with this implemented, I can do cross-architecture testing of it on XFS and BTRFS (unfortunately, I don't have access to an NFS server that supports server-side copies, or any SCSI hardware that supports the XCOPY command).

Also, on the note of Linux specifically, I _think_ that copy_file_range(2) just works, even if the FS doesn't have specific handling for accelerating the copy, but I'm not certain about that.

@Ferroin copy_file_range(2) handles the fallback, given the right flags (or just using the default 0). It will copy the file, but without moving everything through userspace. But we need to make sure to test for kernel versions 4.4+.

@calmh I have thought about hooking into `fs.File` aswell. I like your approach, I think it's quite elegant that way.

Note that when copying blocks we anyway read and hash the block to make sure we get what the database says we should expect, so any "not moving through user space" advantage doesn't apply to us at all. Don't expect this to be a win other than in the cases where you get space savings in the file system, and in those cases count on having to do both a read plus as a copy-range per block.

It would also probably be a win in cases where the files are on an NFS share that supports server side copies (one of the two required round trips to the server would be much smaller) or where the kernel takes advantage of data copy commands at the block device level (I'm pretty sure that copy_file_range(2) can translate to a SCSI XCOPY command if the block device supports it, which ends up avoiding not only userspace, but also kernel operations).  Both cases are of course not likely usage for normal users, but they will still likely see better performance.

The performance boost when reflinks are supported should still be significant though, even with the need to read and hash the block anyway, especially when dealing with devices that take longer to write than to read.

issue.body:
Syncthing should use the [FICLONERANGE](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/ioctl_ficlonerange.2.html) ioctl to clone data it already has instead of doing a dumb `read` + `write`.

This would improve performance and disk usage immensely on CoW filesystems.

I ran into this scenario today. I have one shared folder with the following structure:
```
root
    directory
        subdirectory{0..n}
```
It has about 360GB of stuff scattered amongst the subdirectories.

I decided to reorganize `directory` by adding one additional level of "category" directories and moving the original subdirectories into them:
```
root
    directory
        category{0..n}
            subdirectory{0..n}
```
Then I ran the folder rescan. Once the remote device started updating, it took a very long time. In total only about 120MB were transferred, so it clearly knew to get the data from the files it already had.

I did a cursory `find . -type f -exec stat -c '%w %i %n' | sort` in the directory on the remote side afterwards, and it seems that while it was able to do a file move for about half of the files, for some reason it decided to create new files and dutifully - but slowly - copy the contents over from the old files, over the course of about 2 hours.

If it had instead cloned the data from the old files, it would have been done much quicker and without extra disk usage.

body: Note also that NTFS supports a similar type of deduplication, but only via whole-volume sweep operations (as far as I can find anyway.)  As such integrating a call to the deduplicate mechanism would require a slightly different strategy (call when sync completed instead of per-file probably) and provide no noticeable speed benefits, but if the code can be structured to make doing so feasible then users could at least get the space-saving benefits when duplicate chunks are detected without having to regularly grovel over the whole file system looking for them when they don't exist.

Unpatched RHEL 8.1 has a dataloss problem using copy_file_range. I don't know whether syncthing will trigger it, but the potential damage is serious enough that one of the syncthing devs should look at https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1803162 .
Noted. That's a kernel bug, so the solution seems to be to not enable this entirely optional Syncthing feature on such a system, or to upgrade the kernel.

> Noted. That's a kernel bug, so the solution seems to be to not enable this entirely optional Syncthing feature on such a system, or to upgrade the kernel.

Any user aware of the problem would have upgraded their kernel. The easiest thing for ST to do is to avoid using copy_file_range on RHEL 8.1 (the current version is 8.2). I would not take chances with silent data corruption.

We are going to start targeting and working around distro specific bugs.

Go itself will start using copy_file_range unconditionally in the next version, so sadly users will have to suck it up  if they decide to enable this optional feature.

For people finding this ticket in the future.
This is now implemented as an optional configuration, but the default behaviour remains the same, copy data into application memory.

You can find the docs for the feature here: https://docs.syncthing.net/advanced/folder-copyrangemethod.html
